To build debian packages, ensure that you have the necessary build-dependencies installed,
indicated in the file 'debian/control' in the 'Build-Depends' field.
The following command will install the build dependencies:
sudo apt install debhelper ant debconf default-jdk gettext libgmp-dev po-debconf fakeroot \
build-essential quilt dh-apparmor libservice-wrapper-java libjson-simple-java devscripts \
libjetty9-java libtomcat9-java libtaglibs-standard-jstlel-java libgetopt-java
Additionally, for runtime dependencies (console flags and geoip database):
sudo apt install geoip-database famfamfam-flag-png
Once the dependencies are installed, run 'ant debian' to patch the source and build packages.
To build using ant, there are a few basic requirements:
* Ensure your locale is set to UTF-8
* A Java JDK installation - Oracle, OpenJDK or Microsoft work well
* If you're building updates to be shared, building with Java 8 is recommended, though not required
* The ant-contrib package is a required dependency which supports various ant extensions
* For translation support, GNU gettext is required, and can be installed from repos in most Linux distros
* To enable Javascript compression of the console and webapp scripts, the uglifyjs package is required
* To enable HTML compression of javadocs, the minify package is required
* To build pack200 updates, Java 13 or earlier is required; on Linux, the GNU parallel package is also required
* On a Linux system with multiple Java installations, you can configure ant to use a specific version by setting
an alias in your ~/.bashrc file, e.g. alias ant8="JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.8.0-openjdk-amd64 ant"
